It is the most commonly used letter in many languages, including:Czech languageCzech,cite webhttp://www.bckelk.ukfsn.org/words/etaoin.htmlLetter frequenciesKelkBrianUK Free Software Network2008-06-25Danish languageDanish,Dutch languageDutch,English languageEnglish,cite webhttp://pages.central.edu/emp/LintonT/classes/spring01/cryptography/letterfreq.htmlRelative Frequencies of Letters in General English Plain textLewandRobertCryptographical Mathematics[[Central College (Iowa)|Central College]]2008-06-25French languageFrench,cite webhttp://www.santacruzpl.org/readyref/files/g-l/ltfrqfr.shtmlFrequency of Occurrence of Letters in FrenchSanta Cruz Public Libraries2008-06-25German languageGerman,cite webhttp://scplweb.santacruzpl.org/readyref/files/g-l/ltfrqger.shtmlFrequency of Occurrence of Letters in GermanSanta Cruz Public Libraries2008-06-25Hungarian languageHungarian,Latin languageLatin,Norwegian languageNorwegian,Spanish languageSpanish,cite webhttp://www.santacruzpl.org/readyref/files/g-l/ltfrqsp.shtmlFrequency of Occurrence of Letters in SpanishSanta Cruz Public Libraries2008-06-25andSwedish languageSwedish.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: The Latin letter 'E' differs little from its derivational source, theGreek alphabetGreekletterepsilon, ''. Inetymology, theSemiticHe (letter)h  has been suggested to have started as a praying or calling human figure (hillul'jubilation'), and was probably based on a similarEgyptian hieroglyphthat indicated a different pronunciation. In Semitic, the letter representedIPA/h/(andIPA/e/in foreign words); in Greek,hbecame the letter epsilon, used to representIPA/e/.EtruriaEtruscansandAncient RomeRomansfollowed this usage.
article.heading: Use in writing systems
English
article.paragraph: AlthoughMiddle Englishspelling usedangbreto represent long and short /e/, theGreat Vowel Shiftchanged long /e/ (as in 'me' or 'bee') to /i/ while short /e/ (as in 'met' or 'bed') remained amid vowel. In other cases, the letter isSilent_esilent, generally at the end of words.
article.heading: Other languages
article.paragraph: In the orthography of many languages it represents either these or /IPA link…õ/, or some variation (such as aNasal vowelnasalizedversion) of these sounds, often with diacritics (as:angle brackete [[√™]] [[√©]] [[√®]] [[√´]] [[ƒì]] [[ƒï]] [[ƒõ]] [[·∫Ω]] [[ƒó]] [[·∫π]] [[ƒô]] [[·∫ª]]) to indicate contrasts. Less commonly, as in Saanich,angbrerepresents amid-central vowel//.Digraph (orthography)Digraphswithangbreare common to indicate eitherdiphthongsormonophthongs, such asangbreaorangbreeforIPA/iÀê/orIPA/e…™/in English,angbreiforIPA/a…™/inGerman languageGerman, andangbreuforIPA/√∏/inFrench languageFrenchorIPA/…î…™/in German.
article.heading: Other systems
article.paragraph: TheInternational Phonetic Alphabetusesangbr{{IPA|e}}for theclose-mid front unrounded vowelor themid front unrounded vowel.
article.heading: Most common letter
article.paragraph: 'E' is the most common (or highest-Frequency (statistics)frequency) letter in the English alphabet (starting off the typographer's phraseETAOIN SHRDLU) and several other Europeanlanguages, which has implications in bothcryptographyanddata compression. In the storyThe Gold BugbyEdgar Allan Poe, a character figures out a random character code by remembering that the most used letter in English is E. This makes it a hard and popular letter to use when writinglipograms.Ernest Vincent Wright'sGadsby (novel)Gadsby(1939) is considered a "dreadful" novel, and supposedly "at least part of Wright's narrative issues were caused by language limitations imposed by the lack ofE."Ross Eckler,Making the Alphabet Dance: Recreational Word Play. New York: St. Martin's Press (1996): 3BothGeorges Perec's novelA Void (novel)A Void(La Disparition) (1969) and its English translation by Gilbert Adair omit 'e' and are considered better works.Eckler (1996): 3. Perec's novel "was so well written that at least some reviewers never realized the existence of a letter constraint."

article.heading: Computing codes

template.arg: Also for encodings based on ASCII, including the DOS, Windows, ISO-8859 and Macintosh families of encodings.

article.heading: Other representations
article.paragraph: InBritish Sign Language(BSL), the letter 'e' is signed by extending the index finger of the right hand touching the tip of index on the left hand, with all fingers of left hand open.
